awd_titl_txt: Area-Selective Chemical Vapor Deposition of Thin Films: Suppression of Nucleation on Oxides by Amine Adsorption
awd_abstract_narration:
Advanced microelectronic chips, for both civilian and military applications, should be faster, perform more data operations, and consume less electrical power.  To meet these goals, the size of future devices will be reduced, e.g., the active width of a transistor will be less than 10 nanometers (0.4 millionths of an inch).  Conventional chip fabrication processes involve multiple steps in which a thin layer of material, such as metal, is deposited over the entire area, then a pattern corresponding to the devices is formed over that layer, and unwanted material is removed by chemical etching.  However, at such small size the patterning step becomes significantly difficult and costly because the pattern must align precisely with the partially fabricated device below it.  In response, this project develops an approach that obviates the need for many of the patterning and etching steps: a chemical vapor deposition route is developed such that a layer of material deposits selectively on top of already-existing pattern features, but does not deposit on surfaces where it is not wanted.  It can also enable the fabrication of new, three-dimensional transistor structures and other types of nanoscale device structures beyond microelectronics.  Thus, the results of the project boost the manufacturing capabilities and economic competitiveness of the U.S. high technology industry critical to national prosperity and needed for our national defense systems. The scientific and technical results are reported at major professional conferences, in the peer-reviewed literature, and by seminars at major microelectronic industries.  The project also supports the development of a diverse U.S. workforce through training of graduate student research assistants, who perform this research as the central focus of their dissertation.  

Area-selective deposition of thin metal films by chemical vapor deposition occurs when a suitable amine molecule, such as ammonia, is added to the precursor feedstock, such as a metal carbonyl molecule.  The metal film, such as cobalt or ruthenium, then deposits on conductive substrate features but not on oxide surfaces such as silica, titania, alumina, or magnesia during the time required to grow the desired thickness of metal film.  The role of the amine is to suppress metal nucleation on oxide surfaces, especially those with acidic hydroxyl groups, on which metal islands would otherwise form.  This project tests mechanistic hypotheses concerning the interaction of the amine with the oxide surface and with adsorbed precursor, including the roles of site-blocking and conversion of the surface from acidic to basic character.  Experimental variables include modification of different oxide surfaces, the use of different precursor-amine combinations, growth temperature, and partial pressures.  Analytical methods are in-situ Fourier transform IR spectroscopy to detect the identity of adsorbates, and spectroscopic ellipsometry to detect the onset of nucleation, and ex-situ microstructural probes of adsorbate bonding and quantity.  The scientific determination of underlying mechanisms will enable the reliable use of this approach for advanced device fabrication, as well as its extension to other precursors, amines and surfaces.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Area of Investigation

This project investigates the science behind a special process that can occur during the growth (deposition) of a thin film (coating) using the technique of chemical vapor deposition (CVD), which is used extensively in the manufacturing of microelectronic circuits and other nanoscale advanced devices.  The starting point for CVD is the existence of a volatile molecule (the precursor) that contains the elements to be deposited.  This molecule is flowed into a growth system that is maintained at low pressure by vacuum pumping.  When the molecule strikes a hot surface, it decomposes (rearranges) to afford the desired solid material as a thin film; any unwanted portions of the molecule desorb from the surface and are pumped away. 

In the special process, called selective deposition, the thin film will grow on certain exposed surfaces, for example metals, but will not grow on other exposed surfaces, for example oxides.  This is possible because the earliest stage of growth, called nucleation, must be initiated by chemically reactive sites on the exposed surface.  If such sites do not exist , or if they are rendered inactive by prior or simultaneous treatment by a second molecule (the inhibitor),  then growth does not initiate on that surface, even while growth occurs readily on other surfaces that offer chemically reactive sites.

Selective deposition can simplify and improve the precision of microelectronics manufacturing.  During manufacturing, a nanoscale pattern of materials exists on the surface, often associated with electrical contacts to and between functional elements such as transistors.  Without selective deposition, the thin film grows everywhere; to achieve a functional pattern of material, unwanted areas must then be removed by high-precision pattern definition (photolithography) and etching steps, which are costly and time consuming.  With selective deposition, the thin film grows only where it is desired, i.e., it follows the pattern of materials on the surface that had been established by earlier processing steps.  Since selective growth precisely follows the existing pattern, there is inherently no misalignment; by contrast, (mis)registry on the nanoscale is a significant issue when photolithography is used to redefine the desired pattern. 

Intellectual Merit

We briefly recap the major findings of this project, which have been reported in peer-reviewed scientific publications.  In addition to fulfilling the goals of this project, we discovered new methods for the growth of ultra-smooth films and for the filling of deep features.

1.  We extended the area-selective growth method to the case of HfB2 CVD using the precursor Hf(BH4)4 on Al2O3 vs. SiO2 surfaces.

2.  We used real-time IR absorption spectroscopy to measure the surface coverage of adsorbed intermediates during selective CVD of HfO2.  We obtained direct evidence that adsorption of an inhibitor species correlates with the observed drop in HfO2 growth rate.

3.  We utilized a new CVD precursor, Mg(NBNB)2, to achieve selective growth between oxide surfaces.  Nucleation occurred readily on ruthenium and tungsten oxides, which are the most acidic, whereas nucleation was considerably delayed on silica, alumina, hafnia, and titania.

4.  We discovered that CVD precursors, when utilized below their reaction temperature, can serve as growth rate inhibitors that enhance conformal growth.  This was demonstrated using the precursors AlH3NMe3, Hf(BH4)4, and AlMe3. 

5.  We developed a method to increase nucleation density to very high values using adsorption of an ALD precursor.  In combination with a growth rate inhibitor, we achieved ultra-low surface roughness (< 0.5 nm) on ultra-thin Co films (< 2 nm). 

6.  We analyzed thin film nucleation and coalescence using Monte-Carlo methods and demonstrated that film roughness and mean thickness at coalescence exhibit power law relationships vs. the nucleation rate.

7.  We invented a new CVD approach that affords superconformal deposition and seam-free filling in deep trenches.  The method is based on competitive adsorption between two precursors.  We demonstrated superconformal growth of Co and trench filling with HfB2.

Broader Impacts

The publication of these results and presentation at professional conferences has stimulated, both in academia and in industry, a recognition of the capability of CVD, when used with carefully designed precursor and inhibitor molecules, to afford control over film growth in a manner that meets the requirements for advanced microelectronics fabrication.    

This work was carried out by two graduate students who earned their PhD degrees and are now working in the Microelectronics industry; by one current Postdoctoral researcher; and by one undergraduate REU student, who is now a first-year PhD student in Materials Science at Georgia Tech.  Thus, the program has contributed significantly to the education and training of professionals for the U.S. workforce.
